title: What you need to know about 529 plans for college savings
text:
What you need to know about 529 plans for college savings Use your key for the next article School Photo by Joe Raedle/Getty Images 
Most parents are eager for their children to prepare for higher education but the cost of college is a big barrier for most families. There are many ways to help children cover college expenses; such as student loans, part time jobs, scholarships, living at home, etc. 
Another important step is to start funding a college savings plan as early as possible. 
One type of college savings account is the 529 plan that is offered by each state and has a flexible tax advantage. 
How is the account used? 
The savings account accumulates tax free and can be used for tuition, books, and other education expenses for a two or four year accredited college, university or technical school. The child or student is the beneficiary of the account. 
Taxes 
One the best features of 529 plans are that they offer a significant tax advantage. All money in the account grows tax-free and all withdrawals that are used for qualified higher education expenses are exempt from federal income tax. 
Ownership The account holder maintains control of the assets regardless of the beneficiaryâ€™s (student's) age. You can even hold an account for your own education purposes and be both the owner and the beneficiary of the account. 
If the beneficiary (student) decides not to attend college, you can still change the beneficiary to another family member 
Investment The investment selection within a 529 plan typically offers a choice of mutual funds and an age-based portfolio. The age-based portfolio takes a mix of stocks, bonds and money market mutual funds and adjusts it according to the age of the child. So, as the child gets older, the portfolio mix becomes more conservative to lower the investment risk, as college needs get closer. 
Before you invest, consult with a financial adviser and do your own research.
